    "fix @xmath0 and let @xmath1 be a fractional brownian motion with hurst index @xmath2 , defined on some probability space @xmath3 .",
    "assume that @xmath4 is the completed @xmath5-field generated by @xmath6 .",
    "fix an integer @xmath7 and , for @xmath8 , consider @xmath9 here , and in the rest of this paper , @xmath10 stands for the @xmath11th hermite polynomial .",
    "we have @xmath12 , @xmath13 and so on .    since the seminal works @xcite by breuer , dobrushin , giraitis , major , surgailis and taqqu , the following three convergence results are classical :    * if @xmath14 , then @xmath15 } , \\e^{k(1-h ) -1/2 } g_{\\e }   \\bigr ) \\displaystyle\\mathop{\\stackrel{\\mathrm{law}}{\\longrightarrow}}_{\\e\\to 0 } \\bigl((b_t)_{t\\in[0,t ] } , n   \\bigr),\\ ] ] where @xmath16 is independent of @xmath6 , with @xmath17 ; * if @xmath18 , then @xmath19 } , \\frac{g_{\\e } } { \\sqrt{\\log(1/\\e ) } }   \\biggr ) \\displaystyle\\mathop{\\stackrel {   \\mathrm{law}}{\\longrightarrow}}_{\\e\\to 0   } \\bigl((b_t)_{t\\in[0,t ] } , n   \\bigr),\\ ] ] where @xmath20 is independent of @xmath6 ; * if @xmath21 , then @xmath22 where @xmath23 denotes the hermite random variable of order @xmath11 ; see section  [ sec31 ] for its definition .",
    "combining ( [ cv < ] ) with the fact that @xmath24<\\infty$ ] for all @xmath25 ( use the boundedness of @xmath26 and a classical hypercontractivity argument ) , we have , for all @xmath27 and if @xmath28 , that @xmath29 \\mathop{\\longrightarrow}_{\\e\\to 0 } e(\\eta   n)=e(\\eta)e(n)=0\\ ] ] ( a similar statement holds in the critical case @xmath30 ) .",
    "this means that @xmath31 converges _ weakly _ in @xmath32 to zero .",
    "the following question then arises .",
    "is there a normalization of @xmath33 ensuring that it converges _ weakly _ towards a _ non - zero _ limit when @xmath34 ?",
    "if so , then what can be said about the limit ?",
    "the first purpose of the present paper is to provide an answer to this question in the framework of _ white noise analysis_.    in @xcite , it is shown that for all @xmath2 , the time derivative @xmath35 ( called the _ fractional white noise _ ) is a distribution in the sense of hida .",
    "we also refer to bender @xcite , biagini _ et al . _",
    "@xcite and references therein for further works on the fractional white noise .",
    "since we have @xmath36 , observe that @xmath33 defined in ( [ geps ] ) can be rewritten as @xmath37 where @xmath38 denotes the @xmath11th wick product . in proposition  [ thm - fbm ]",
    "below , we will show that for all @xmath39 , @xmath40 where the limit is in the @xmath41 sense .",
    "in particular , we observe two different types of asymptotic results for @xmath42 when @xmath43 : convergence ( [ cvwick ] ) in @xmath41 to a hida distribution , and convergence ( [ cv < ] ) in law to a normal law , with rate @xmath44 . on the other hand , when @xmath45 , we obtain from ( [ cv > ] ) that the hida distribution @xmath46 turns out to be the square - integrable random variable @xmath47 , which is an interesting result in its own right .    in proposition",
    "[ cvs * ] , the convergence ( [ cvwick ] ) in @xmath41 is proved for a general class of volterra processes of the form @xmath48 where @xmath49 stands for a standard brownian motion , provided the kernel @xmath50 satisfies some suitable conditions ; see section  [ volterra ]",
    ".    we also provide a new proof of the convergence ( [ cv < ] ) based on the recent general criterion for the convergence in distribution to a normal law of a sequence of multiple stochastic integrals established by nualart and peccati @xcite and by peccati and tudor @xcite , which avoids the classical method of moments .    in two recent papers @xcite , marcus and rosen",
    "have obtained central and non - central limit theorems for a functional of the form ( [ geps ] ) , where @xmath6 is a mean zero gaussian process with stationary increments such that the covariance function of @xmath6 , defined by @xmath51 , is either convex ( plus some additional regularity conditions ) , concave or given by @xmath52 with @xmath53 .",
    "these theorems include the convergence ( [ cv < ] ) and , unlike our simple proof , are based on the method of moments .",
    "in the second part of the paper , we develop a similar analysis for functionals of two independent fractional brownian motions ( or , more generally , volterra processes ) related to the lvy area .",
    "more precisely , consider two _ independent _ fractional brownian motions @xmath54 and @xmath55 with ( for simplicity ) the same hurst index @xmath2 .",
    "we are interested in the convergence , as @xmath56 , of @xmath57 and @xmath58 note that @xmath59 coincides with the @xmath60-integral associated with the forward russo ",
    "vallois integral @xmath61 ; see , for example , @xcite and references therein . over the last decade , the convergences of @xmath59 and @xmath62 ( or of related families of random variables ) have been intensively studied .",
    "since @xmath63 converges pointwise to @xmath64 for any @xmath65 , we could think that the asymptotic behaviors of @xmath59 and @xmath62 are very close as @xmath66 .",
    "surprisingly , this is not the case .",
    "actually , only the result for @xmath62 agrees with the seminal result of coutin and qian @xcite ( that is , we have convergence of @xmath62 in @xmath32 if and only if @xmath67 ) and with the recent result by unterberger @xcite ( that is , adequately renormalized , @xmath62 converges in law if @xmath68 ) .",

    "in this section , we present some preliminaries on white noise analysis .",
    "the classical approach to white noise distribution theory is to endow the space of tempered distributions @xmath98 with a  gaussian measure @xmath99 such that , for any rapidly decreasing function @xmath100 , @xmath101 here , @xmath102 denotes the norm in @xmath103 and @xmath104 the dual pairing between @xmath98 and @xmath105 .",
    "the existence of such a measure is ensured by minlos theorem @xcite .    in this way",

    "in this section , we provide a new proof of these convergences by means of a recent criterion for the weak convergence of sequences of multiple stochastic integrals established in @xcite and @xcite .",
    "we refer to @xcite for a proof in the case of more general gaussian processes , using different kind of tools .",
    "let us first recall the aforementioned criterion .",
    "we continue to use the notation introduced in section  [ sec31 ] .",

    "the proof of ( [ toshow2 ] ) will be achieved by showing that the expectation ( resp .",
    ", the variance ) of @xmath520 tends to @xmath521 ( resp . , zero ) .",
    "by step  1 , observe that @xmath522 as @xmath66 .",
    "we now want to show that the variance of @xmath523 converges to zero .",
    "performing the changes of variables @xmath524 and @xmath525 yields @xmath526^{2}}(b_{s/\\varepsilon + 1}-b_{s/\\varepsilon } ) ( b_{t/\\varepsilon + 1}-b_{t/\\varepsilon } ) \\biggl(\\int_{0}^{s/\\varepsilon } \\int_{0}^{t/\\varepsilon } \\rho ( v - v^{\\prime } ) \\,\\mathrm{d}v\\,\\mathrm{d}v^{\\prime } \\biggr ) \\,\\mathrm{d}s\\,\\mathrm{d}t,\\ ] ] which has the same distribution as @xmath527^{2}}(b_{s+\\varepsilon } -b_{s})(b_{t+\\varepsilon } -b_{t } ) \\biggl ( \\int_{0}^{s/\\varepsilon } \\int_{0}^{t/\\varepsilon } \\rho ( u - u ' ) \\,\\mathrm{d}u\\,\\mathrm{d}u '   \\biggr ) \\,\\mathrm{d}s\\,\\mathrm{d}t \\\\ & = & \\varepsilon ^{-1 - 2h}\\int_{[0,t]^{2}}(b_{s+\\varepsilon } -b_{s})(b_{t+\\varepsilon } -b_{t})\\lambda _ { \\varepsilon } ( s , t)\\,\\mathrm{d}s\\,\\mathrm{d}t,\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where @xmath528 this can be written as @xmath529 where @xmath530}(s ) \\mathbf{1}_{[\\varepsilon , t+\\varepsilon ] } ( t)\\lambda _ { \\varepsilon}(s-\\varepsilon , t-\\varepsilon ) -\\mathbf{1}_{[0,t]}(s)\\mathbf{1}_{[\\varepsilon , t+\\varepsilon ] } ( t)\\lambda _ { \\varepsilon } ( s , t-\\varepsilon ) \\nonumber \\\\[-8pt]\\\\[-8pt ] & & { } -\\mathbf{1}_{[\\varepsilon , t+\\varepsilon ] } ( s)\\mathbf{1}_{[0,t]}(t)\\lambda_{\\varepsilon } ( s-\\varepsilon , t)+\\mathbf{1}_{[0,t]}(s)\\mathbf{1}_{[0,t]}(t)\\lambda _ { \\varepsilon } ( s , t).\\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] moreover , @xmath531}\\otimes \\mathbf{1}_{[0,t ] } \\sigma_{\\varepsilon } ( s , t)\\,\\mathrm{d}s\\,\\mathrm{d}t \\biggr),\\ ] ] where @xmath532 is the double stochastic integral with respect to @xmath6 .",
    "therefore , @xmath533}\\otimes \\mathbf{1}_{[0,t]}\\sigma _ { \\varepsilon } ( s , t)\\,\\mathrm{d}s\\,\\mathrm{d}t\\bigg\\|^2_{\\hh^{\\otimes 2 } } \\\\ & = & 2\\varepsilon ^{-2 - 4h}\\int_{\\mathbb{r}^{4}}r_{h}(s , s^{\\prime } ) r_{h}(t , t^{\\prime } ) \\sigma _ { \\varepsilon } ( s , t)\\sigma _ { \\varepsilon } ( s^{\\prime } , t^{\\prime } ) \\,\\mathrm{d}s\\,\\mathrm{d}t\\,\\mathrm{d}s^{\\prime } \\,\\mathrm{d}t^{\\prime } .\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] taking into account that the partial derivatives @xmath534 and @xmath535 are integrable , we can write @xmath536 hence , by integrating by parts , we get @xmath537 from ( [ e1 ] ) , we obtain @xmath538}(s ) \\bigl ( \\mathbf{1}_{[0,\\varepsilon ] } ( t)- \\mathbf{1}_{[t , t+\\varepsilon ] } ( t ) \\bigr ) \\int_{s-\\varepsilon } ^{s}\\lambda_{\\varepsilon } ( \\sigma , t-\\varepsilon ) \\,\\mathrm{d}\\sigma.\\ ] ] in the same way , @xmath539}(t^{\\prime } ) \\bigl ( \\mathbf{1}_{[0,\\varepsilon ] } ( s^{\\prime } ) -\\mathbf{1}_{[t , t+\\varepsilon ] } ( s^{\\prime } ) \\bigr ) \\int_{t^{\\prime } -\\varepsilon } ^{t^{\\prime } } \\lambda _ { \\varepsilon } ( s^{\\prime } -\\varepsilon,\\tau ) \\,\\mathrm{d}\\tau.\\ ] ] as a consequence , @xmath540}(s ) \\bigl ( \\mathbf{1}_{[0,\\varepsilon ] } ( t)-\\mathbf{1}_{[t , t+\\varepsilon ] } ( t ) \\bigr )   \\\\ & & \\hspace*{53pt}{}\\times \\mathbf{1}_{[0,t]}(t^{\\prime } ) \\bigl ( \\mathbf{1}_{[0,\\varepsilon]}(s^{\\prime } ) -\\mathbf{1}_{[t , t+\\varepsilon ] } ( s^{\\prime } ) \\bigr ) \\,\\mathrm{d}s\\,\\mathrm{d}t\\,\\mathrm{d}s^{\\prime } \\,\\mathrm{d}t^{\\prime } = \\sum_{i=1}^{4}h_{\\varepsilon } ^{i},\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where @xmath541 and @xmath542 we only consider the term @xmath543 because the others can be handled in the same way .",
    "we have , with @xmath182 given by ( [ ppssii ] ) , @xmath544 note that @xmath545 for any @xmath546 $ ] . therefore , @xmath547 and we obtain the estimate @xmath548 as a consequence , @xmath549 which converges to zero because @xmath550 .",
    "recall the definition ( [ hat ] ) of @xmath97 , @xmath551 we have the following result .    [ cvgausscovariation ] convergences ( [ star5 ] ) and ( [ star6 ] ) hold .",
    "we use the same trick as in @xcite , remark 1.3 , point 4 .",
    "let @xmath552 and @xmath553 be two independent one - dimensional fractional brownian motions with index @xmath282 .",
    "set @xmath554 and @xmath555 .",
    "it is easily checked that @xmath54 and @xmath55 are also two independent fractional brownian motions with index @xmath282 .",
    "moreover , we have @xmath556 the proofs of the desired convergences in law are now direct consequences of the convergence ( [ cv < ] ) with @xmath355 , taking into account that @xmath552 and @xmath553 are independent .    as a by - product of the decomposition ( [ dollar ] ) , and taking into account ( [ cv > ] ) for @xmath355",
    ", we get that @xmath557 and @xmath558 have the same law when @xmath94 , where @xmath559 stands for an independent copy of the hermite random variable @xmath560 .",
    "the research of i. nourdin was supported in part by the anr project ` exploration des chemins rugueux ' .",
    "the research of d. nualart was supported by nsf grant dms-0904538 .",
    "biagini , f. , ksendal , b. , sulem , a. and wallner , n. ( 2004 ) .",
    "an introduction to white noise theory and malliavin calculus for fractional brownian motion .",
    "ser . a math .",
    "sci . _ * 460 * 347372 .",
    "nourdin , i. , nualart , d. and tudor , c.a .",
    "central and non - central limit theorems for weighted power variations of fractional brownian motion .",
    "h. poincar probab .",
    "_ to appear .",
    "unterberger , j. ( 2008 ) .",
    "a central limit theorem for the rescaled lvy area of two - dimensional fractional brownian motion with hurst index @xmath68 .",
    "available at http://arxiv.org/abs/0808.3458[arxiv : 0808.3458 ] ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> by means of white noise analysis , we prove some limit theorems for nonlinear functionals of a given volterra process . in particular , our results apply to fractional brownian motion ( fbm ) and should be compared with the classical convergence results of the 1980s due to breuer , dobrushin , giraitis , major , surgailis and taqqu , as well as the recent advances concerning the construction of a lvy area for fbm due to coutin , qian and unterberger .    , </S>"
  ]
}
